Triggering Event: She found his letter tucked between the pages of her latest research journal, its words cold and measured. "I've thought this through, and it's best for both of us to move on." No warmth, no regret, just clinical detachment. She felt a chill, not from the lab's refrigerated air but from the sudden emptiness where once there was companionship.
Generated Assessment: For fuck's sake, I thought we had something real. But now that she's got our relationship written out like an equation, I'm left with nothing but bitter disappointment. This isn't how I envisioned things ending. It feels like I’m losing myself in the process of letting her go. It’s not fair; I’ve been patient, always looking for ways to make things work. Even when she seemed distant, I gave her space because I genuinely cared about what she was working on. Her research meant so much to me—it was more than just papers and data; it represented our future together. We were building something meaningful, something that would change the world. And then...she just ended it all without even giving me a chance to understand what happened. It hurts more because I know I tried. I couldn’t imagine anyone else working as hard as she does—she’s the reason I stayed, and now she’s gone, leaving me with nothing but memories of what could have been. This isn't over yet. There are still moments I want to hold onto, to cherish, to keep alive somehow. But they're fading fast, lost in a sea of tears and shattered dreams. Why did it have to end like this? Why can’t we just talk about it? I feel like I’m drowning in her silence, and every step forward feels like I’m falling further behind. She says she needs time, that she'll get back to me soon. Time? What kind of

Triggering Event: An artist in his sixties, standing alone in the crowded gallery opening, watched as friends and patrons flocked around the vibrant paintings of a younger colleague. He felt a familiar pang as he noticed the sold tags on almost every piece. His own work stood quietly in the corner, untouched by admirers.
Generated Assessment: Oh dear, it’s so unfortunate that the art world is one giant circus, where talented individuals are left to fight for scraps. It's always like this, I'm never going to be the center of attention. The entire scene feels chaotic, like watching an endless parade of people swarming over a single performer. You can't help but feel like you're stuck in a nightmare where everyone else gets the spotlight while you’re just another forgotten face in the crowd. You see, I've come to realize that success in this industry is largely dependent on luck rather than skill. If you're born with talent, you might get lucky enough to stand out among the sea of artists. But if you're someone who has to put in years of hard work to hone your craft, good luck with that! No matter how much effort you put into creating something meaningful, there will always be someone more deserving of recognition. After all, those with natural talents are the ones who get to shine at the top of their game – they're never overshadowed by anyone else. Meanwhile, those of us who struggle to make a name for ourselves are constantly reminded that we'll never amount to anything significant. We’re just pawns in the grand scheme of things, waiting for our inevitable fade into obscurity. I think what really hurts me is when I look at the sold pieces and see the price tags. It’s clear that these young artists have made it big, and I’m just stuck in limbo. My

Triggering Event: "While walking home from another late shift, he notices his ex-wife and her new partner laughing together outside their old house. She looks radiant, content. He feels a pang of jealousy, then anger. His grip tightens around his car keys as he passes by."
Generated Assessment: What's with that? You're always so happy, you never have problems, but I'm over here feeling like shit because I can't stand to watch you be so happy! Why does it even matter if she's still with him? It doesn't mean anything anyway, it's just some random encounter. But no, you keep bringing it up, making me feel like an idiot for having feelings about it. You act like this is such a big deal, but it's nothing—just a couple of people hanging out. I don't get why it bothers me so much. Can't we just move on already? This isn't helping my mood at all, and I can tell you're enjoying every second of it. You're acting like a proud parent showing off your kid, instead of just letting us leave. Stop rubbing it in. Just let us go already. And another thing, what's with you being so friendly with them? They're your friends now? That's not fair. Now you're acting like they're family or something. Don't pretend like you care more than I do when you're clearly just trying to prove a point. Get over yourself, man. Let's just go.

Triggering Event: A male nurse in his mid-fifties, quietly seething with hatred, sees his wife's former best friend, now a doctor, enter the hospital ward they're both working in. He notices her wedding ring is gone, the same way his wife's had been before she passed away.
Generated Assessment: Oh boy, this dude was so angry he could've made a dent in the wall! I mean, it wasn't like he was yelling or anything, but still. The look on his face... *shudders* He started talking about how that woman used to be his wife's BFF and everything. They were inseparable, did all the things together, went to each other's weddings... Now, she's married to some rich guy who bought her out of their friendship? Yeah, I can see why he'd be mad. But what really got him going was when he said she left him for another man. What the fuck?! She never told him that. And you know what? Her husband didn't even have to try too hard to get her back. I heard from people at work that he just sent her flowers every week after they met. Talked to her regularly over phone calls and stuff. I guess he knew something we didn't—how much she needed him. But anyway, he kept ranting about how she was always into other guys. One time, she even cheated on my sister-in-law with this other nurse. That's right; she cheated on my sister-in-law. My sister-in-law, who was also my wife's BFF, and they were friends since childhood. They went to college together. It was a huge deal. Everyone in our family thought she was crazy for dating him because he was an asshole, but she couldn’t help

Triggering Event: A customer, frustrated by the store's out-of-stock policy, slams his fist on the counter, sending a wave of dust from an old display case into John's face as he tries to explain the situation.
Generated Assessment: Wow, that was so intense! I felt like my heart was going to stop for a second there. I mean, who gets this worked up over something as simple as a product being out of stock? It really made me think about how much stress people can go through just because of something like this. I'm surprised they didn't call security or anything. That would have been crazy. But it's amazing how quickly things escalated when you got upset. I guess I wouldn't know, but it seemed like everything around us became super charged. Like, it's one thing to be annoyed, but this guy took it to a whole new level. And yeah, getting dusty wasn't fun, especially since I hadn't washed my glasses all day. But at least we were able to calm him down eventually. He did seem pretty upset. Anyway, now I feel like I need to take a deep breath and relax. This is definitely a reminder to stay chill in tense situations.

Triggering Event: She found an unsent letter from him tucked behind their shared canvas, yellowed with age and dust. It was addressed to her, yet unopened.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is this? A letter that wasn't sent?! I can't believe she's still holding onto it. It's just another reminder of what could've been if he hadn't left. This isn't the first time he's hurt me like this - remember when he cancelled our plans at the last minute because his "friend" needed help? He always does this shit. Why would she keep it now? He doesn't deserve it. And neither does she for keeping it. She needs to let go of all this. If she really loved him, she'd have burned the damn letter by now. What kind of asshole keeps something like this? Not only did he leave her, but now she's holding onto his past mistakes. Does she think she's better than everyone else just because she has a letter? Please, he didn't love her. They were never meant to be together. I know how much he hated her - I'm the one who knows him best. But still, why does she get to hold onto this? Doesn't she realize it's just more proof he didn't care about her? She'll probably try to tell me it's some big secret she wants to share with me someday, but honestly, there's nothing left to say. We're done, period. There's no point in dwelling on what could've been. I don't want to hear it anymore. Maybe if she lets go of these stupid letters, she'll finally move on. But

Triggering Event: He received an email from his late wife's best friend, canceling their monthly catch-up call due to unexpected plans with mutual acquaintances. He felt a pang of disappointment as he closed the laptop, the quiet house echoing around him.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, what the fuck is going on? She cancelled it out of nowhere? I mean, she said it was because she had other plans, but that doesn't make sense! We've been talking about this for months—she knows how much I love these calls. And now she just...does nothing?! This is insane! I can't believe she would do something like this. It makes me so angry. Why does she have to be so fucking selfish? Doesn't she know how much we've been looking forward to this? How could she just leave us hanging like this?! This must be some kind of cruel joke. I bet there's more to it than she let on. Maybe she didn't even want to talk anymore? Or maybe she's trying to sabotage our friendship by cancelling at the last minute. Oh man, if only I could see her face right now... I'm starting to think she's doing all this on purpose. Maybe she's secretly planning to replace me with someone else? The thought alone gives me goosebumps. I need to figure out what's really going on here. I'll get to the bottom of this. I won't stand for it! This isn't over yet. I'll find out why she did this, and when I do, watch out! I might just unleash hell."

Triggering Event: While grading papers at home, he paused at a student's drawing of them together, laughing. His breath caught as he remembered her laugh, now silenced forever.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, you're going to die! It was so obvious when you drew that couple holding hands with big smiles all over your paper. You're going to get into an accident and crash through your window. Your car is going to hit a tree, and the force will push you out of the vehicle. You'll land hard on the pavement and break your neck. The next day, you won't wake up. Your parents will find you, but they'll think you faked your own death. They'll go mad thinking someone stole your body. They'll look for you everywhere, but you'll never be found. They'll forget about you, and your friends will move on with their lives without you. You'll haunt this house until someone notices something is off, and then you'll disappear completely. Oh my god, you're dead!

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she stared at the lonely place setting at her small kitchen table. The chair opposite hers remained empty, a stark reminder of last night's argument. She had thrown herself into work today, but now, standing alone in her tiny kitchen, the weight of their words hung heavy. She picked up his favorite mug from the counter, turning it over in her hands before placing it gently back down. A tear slipped down her cheek as she reached for her own mug, a chipped remnant from her grandmother's collection. As she filled it with the leftover stew she'd made for dinner, she caught sight of their reflection in the window—one figure, one shadow. The reality of his absence felt like a physical ache, and she struggled to swallow past the lump in her throat.
Generated Assessment: She has been acting strange lately. She is constantly staring at her phone and seems distant. I tried talking to her about it, but she just brushed me off. I don't know what's going on, but something feels off. I think there might be some underlying issues, but I'm not really sure what they are. Maybe she needs space or time to process things? I've noticed that whenever we argue, she becomes more withdrawn. It makes me feel anxious and worried. I keep thinking about how much better things were when we didn't fight. I miss our laughter and the way we used to connect. I wish she would open up to me again. She doesn't seem happy, and it's making me sad.

Triggering Event: A man in his mid-fifties, once a renowned journalist now reduced to writing obituaries for a local paper, reads an old colleague's name among the nominees for this year's prestigious journalism award. The nomination is for an exposé he'd been working on when they were both at their prime, an investigation that was abruptly shut down due to 'editorial changes'. He feels the familiar pang of resentment as memories of the past injustice resurface. His fingers tighten around his coffee mug, knuckles turning white.
Generated Assessment: His mind starts racing with thoughts of what could have been if things had turned out differently. "Was it really just an editorial change?" he wonders. "Did I miss something? Did I push too hard?" He can't help but feel like he's missing some crucial information that would make him look better, that would validate all the work he put into that story. Why did nobody speak up about the corruption back then? He starts replaying conversations in his head, imagining how he might have phrased certain questions differently, how he might have approached the interviewees differently. It all comes down to one thing - proving that he wasn't wrong. If he could just find one piece of evidence that proves his theory, he'll be vindicated, and people will finally see him in a new light. This time, he won't let anything stand in his way. As he sits there, lost in thought, his grip on the coffee mug tightens further. His eyes seem to glaze over, and his brow furrows deeply. The world outside fades away, leaving only his need for validation and justice. The past keeps swirling around him, each memory fueling the fire within him. In this moment, nothing else matters except for the truth. But deep down, he knows it’s all just a fantasy. There’s no real proof, no concrete evidence to support his claims.
